page.title: 02RURAL FARMING - GENERAL
page.content: Farming in this area is a mixture of hill farming involving mainly sheep and "hill" or suckler cows which can live on the poor grazing land of higher ground, and lowland farming by dairy farmers. Depending on the quality of the land, the average cost per acre is approximately Â£1800-Â£2000 and the average farmer, possesses 80 cows per 100 acres of lowland. The main problem which farmers encounter daily is illness in stock, but the weather also hampers haytime and affects crops and milk yield. A health inspector visits the farm regularly. Farmers like to administer their own drugs and only call the vet in severe cases. Every ten years a safety inspector makes extensive checks. There is no restriction upon the use of fertilisers and lime and slag are widely used.
